_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Portable handheld photoionization detector to read ammonia in atmosphere
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Table-Top Training with LEPC and Lincoln Fire & Rescue Department
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Standard operation of the NH3 equipment tasks an instrumentation check the system at the start of each cooling season.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Rokeby Generating Station has a Release Prevention Program in place to prevent accidental releases of hazardous materials at this facility. The Release Prevention Program includes:



Safety Information (SI)

LES develops and keeps current working copies of SI documentation including information pertaining to hazards of the process, the technology of the process and the equipment of the process. This information is used to inform both employees and contractors.



Hazard Review (HR)

LES is committed to performing HRs to identify, evaluate and control hazards associated with Operating Procedures (OPs). Rokeby Station has developed OPs as required and keeps them current.



Training

LES is committed to providing employees with comprehensive training to assure that the workforce can perform their duties safely, efficiently and effectively.



Maintenance

LES has developed a maintenance program for the ammonia system at Rokeby Generating Station. The maintenance program includes pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems and ancillary equipment, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency

shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance procedures are developed or promulgated by equipment vendors, federal or state regulations, or industry codes.



Incident Investigation

The LES Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan for Rokeby Generating Station has well defined incident reporting and investigation procedures. Responsibilities, titles and phone numbers are provided therein.



40 CFR 668.155(e) The Five-Year Accident History

The Rokeby Station has not had a reportable accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years. 



40 CFR 68.155(f) The Emergency Response Program

LES has a detailed Emergency Ammonia Release Response Plan designated specifically for

an ammonia release for Rokeby Generating Station. The plan is reviewed with response

organizations on a routine basis.



40 CFR 68.155(g) Planned Changes to Improve Safety

LES will follow up on all of the recommendations of the Risk Management Program in a timely manner.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

40CFR 68.155(a) The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source.



Rokeby Generating Station, owned and operated by Lincoln Electric System (LES), is the

stationary source covered by this Risk Management Plan. LES is a publicly owned electric utility

with sole service responsibility in and around Lincoln, Nebraska. As a publicly owned utility, LES

operates and maintains all of the equipment in our system in a manner representing prudent utility

practices and in conformance with the expectations of LES customer/owner's. LES strives for

excellence in the facility operations and for full compliance with all local, state, and federal laws and

regulations.



Meeting environmental requirements is part of LES business practices and by maintaining this Risk

Management Program LES is complying with the Federal Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR

Part 68) and the Risk Management Program defined in it. LES is committed to the accidental

release prevention program and also maintains a detailed Emergency Response Plan designated

specifically for the Terry Bundy Generating Station. The plan is routinely reviewed with HazMat

responder organizations.



40 CFR 68.155(b) The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled



The Rokeby Station, owned and operated by LES, provides emergency, peaking and base load electric power generation by utilizing one or more of the three dual fuel combustion turbines, two diesel blackstart engines, and one fuel oil storage tank located on the 160-acre onsite. To augment power output during high summer air temperatures, a cooling system is used to lower turbine inlet air temperatures. The cooling system uses ammonia refrigeration to make ice that is stored in two separate concrete tanks with capacities of 1.1 million gallons and 3 million gallons respectively. The cooling system consists of Ice System #1, which was commercial in 1991, and Ice System #2 which was comme

rcial in 1999.



The ammonia refrigeration cooling system contains a total of approximately 29,300 pounds of anhydrous ammonia (Ice System #1 and Ice System #2 combined), and this is the maximum plant inventory. This ammonia quantity requires that Rokeby Station develop a Risk Management Program and Plan. Rokeby Station is covered by Program 2 requirements.
